question: At common law, is there a general duty to rescue a stranger in peril?
choices: A. Yes, a duty always exists
B. No, unless an exception applies
C. Yes, if the rescue would be easy
D. No, because negligence law never recognizes duties
explanation: No general duty to rescue. Exceptions: defendant created the peril, special relationship, or voluntary undertaking.

question: D negligently creates a traffic hazard; P is injured when a third party collides while rubbernecking. Which is most accurate?
choices: A. No duty because third-party acts always break the chain
B. Duty exists if the risk of third-party reactions was reasonably foreseeable
C. No duty absent privity
D. Duty exists only if the third party was negligent per se
explanation: Duty analysis turns on foreseeability and scope of risk; creating a hazard foreseeably invites third‑party reactions.

question: Negligence is typically measured against which standard?
choices: A. Defendant’s best personal judgment
B. The reasonable person
C. Industry custom conclusively
D. What the judge would have done
explanation: Objective reasonable person standard; custom is evidence but not conclusive.

question: Industry custom shows most actors skip a cheap guard that would prevent a serious harm. Best analysis?
choices: A. Custom controls; no breach
B. Evidence of no breach as a matter of law
C. Jury may find breach despite custom
D. Judge decides breach on summary judgment
explanation: Custom is relevant but not controlling. The jury may find breach when reasonable care requires more than customary practice.

question: Which statement best captures but‑for causation?
choices: A. Harm would not have occurred without D’s conduct
B. Harm was foreseeable
C. Harm was within scope of risk
D. D acted intentionally
explanation: But‑for asks whether the injury would have occurred absent the breach.

question: Hospital negligently delays antibiotics, but undisputed evidence shows the infection was already irreversible. Result on actual cause?
choices: A. Satisfied because delay was negligent
B. Not satisfied; harm would have occurred anyway
C. Satisfied because damages are severe
D. Satisfied whenever medical defendants are involved
explanation: If the injury would have occurred regardless, but‑for fails; no actual cause.

question: Two negligent fires, each sufficient to burn P’s house, merge. Under modern approach:
choices: A. Neither is a cause
B. Only the larger fire is a cause
C. Both are treated as actual causes
D. Plaintiff cannot recover
explanation: Restatement (Third): each sufficient cause counts as a factual cause.

question: Two careless drivers independently release toxins, each sufficient to cause P’s identical lung injury. Best causation treatment?
choices: A. Traditional but‑for test excludes both
B. Substantial factor test or Restatement (Third) sufficient‑cause principle includes both
C. Market share liability
D. Alternative liability
explanation: Where each act is sufficient, courts treat each as a cause despite but‑for’s failure.

question: Two hunters are negligent; one bullet hits P but identity is unknown. Which doctrine assists P?
choices: A. Market share liability
B. Alternative liability (burden shifts)
C. Joint and several liability only
D. Negligence per se
explanation: Summers v. Tice shifts the burden to defendants to disprove causation.

question: Alternative liability applies most appropriately when:
choices: A. All defendants acted with due care
B. All defendants were negligent and one (unknown) caused the harm
C. Plaintiff can identify the tortfeasor
D. There were multiple sufficient causes
explanation: Prereqs: all defendants were negligent; only one caused the harm; causal uncertainty justifies burden shifting.

question: Under joint & several liability, plaintiff may:
choices: A. Recover only 50% from each tortfeasor
B. Recover 100% from either tortfeasor for indivisible harm
C. Recover only exact shares as found at trial
D. Not recover when causes are uncertain
explanation: Plaintiff may collect the full judgment from either defendant; contribution sorts it out.

question: P collects entire judgment from D1; what is D1’s recourse against D2?
choices: A. None; double recovery allowed
B. Contribution claim against D2
C. Indemnity is automatic
D. Res judicata bars recovery
explanation: A paying defendant may pursue contribution from other negligent defendants.

question: In DES-type cases, damages may be apportioned:
choices: A. Equally among all defendants
B. By each defendant’s market share of the product
C. Only if actual manufacturer is identified
D. By who sold the last dose
explanation: Sindell: allocate by market share over relevant period.

question: Key disputes in market share liability commonly include:
choices: A. Whether intentional torts are included
B. Defining the relevant market and timeframe
C. Whether negligence per se is constitutional
D. Whether res ipsa applies automatically
explanation: Parties fight over market definition and period because the share controls exposure.

question: An intentional intervening act breaks the chain:
choices: A. Always
B. Never
C. Only if outside the scope of the risk created by D’s negligence
D. Only if D is insolvent
explanation: Scope-of-risk test: intervening criminal/intentional acts can supersede if outside the risk that made D negligent.

question: Landlord blocks a fire exit (negligence). During a fire, a looter bars the door, worsening harm. Liability turns on:
choices: A. Whether looting is more negligent
B. Whether the harm is within the scope of the risk that made the blocked exit negligent
C. Whether joint & several liability applies
D. Whether plaintiff was contributorily negligent per se
explanation: Proximate cause asks whether the injury is a realization of the risk that made D’s conduct negligent.

question: Negligence per se primarily affects which element?
choices: A. Duty/Breach (standard of care)
B. Actual cause
C. Damages
D. Intent
explanation: It substitutes the statutory standard for reasonable care to establish breach if class/type of harm match.

question: Statute requires corrective lenses as indicated on license. D drives without lenses and hits P. What must P still prove?
choices: A. Nothing; negligence per se establishes all elements
B. Only damages
C. Actual and proximate causation
D. That D intended harm
explanation: Negligence per se can establish breach, but plaintiff must still prove causation and damages.

question: Res ipsa allows the jury to:
choices: A. Conclusively presume breach
B. Infer breach from the nature of the accident
C. Ignore causation
D. Award punitive damages automatically
explanation: When the event ordinarily does not occur absent negligence and instrumentality was in D’s control, the jury may infer breach.

question: Which best states res ipsa’s procedural effect?
choices: A. Shifts burden of persuasion on all elements
B. Creates a permissible inference of negligence and may shift the burden of production
C. Bars defendants from presenting evidence
D. Establishes negligence per se
explanation: Res ipsa generally creates an inference and may shift the burden of production, not the ultimate burden of persuasion.
